Hello,

Finally I managed to build the Cantera using Visual Studio 2005 
wi=
thout Python and Matlab bindings. To do this I should clean the 
projects' =
options removing references to unused libraries and correct 
the directory'=
s paths. To check the build, I ran the flamespeed.cpp 
demo from the direct=
ory Cxx/demos. When doing this I encountered a 
few minor problems:  
1.	 F=
ile ck2ctml.cpp. I changed iterators low.begin() and 
high.begin() to the r=
eferences to the first objects:
   addFloatArray(f,"coeffs",low.size(),&low=
[0]);
addFloatArray(fh,"coeffs",high.size(),&high[0]); 

2.	Function ck2ctm=
l produces a file where a node "reactionArray" 
has a child "include" with =
the information about number of reactions 
in the mechanism. The program cr=
ashes when using this file as input 
for the calculation of a free flame. A=
fter removing this "include" 
node the program does not chrashes. It seems =
that this node has no 
influence on the results of the calculations. Can th=
is node be safely 
removed or it is used in other parts of the Cantera?    =


3.	When using oxydizer with the mole fraction of oxygen higher 
than that=
 in air, the program crashes. It happens in the function 
setFixedTemperatu=
re. The reason is that the position of the fixed 
temperature of 900 K in t=
he example is directly after the first 
gridpoint. Therefore, the variable =
m1 remains equal to 0 and when the 
outlet domain is checked in the loop, t=
he point of the fixed 
temperature is put in this domain behind the grid. T=
o fix this, the 
flag  addnewpt should be cleared directly after the if ope=
rator: 
 			if(m=3D=3Dm1&&addnewpt){
			addnewpt =3D false;

After correcti=
ng these problems, the program ran succesfully and 
produced the reasonable=
 results. To print the results of the 
calculatios I used the following sta=
tements:

for(int i =3D 0; i < np; i++)
	{
		flow.setGas(flame.solution()+ =
flame.domain(1).loc
(),i);
		cout << flow.grid(i) <<  "\t" << flow.phase
()=
.temperature() 
			<< "\t" << flow.phase().density()  
			<< "\t" << flow.p=
hase().meanMolecularWeight
()  
<< "\t" << flow.phase().moleFraction("CO2")=
 <<  std::endl;
	}

Is it a correct method to get the gas object in the gri=
dpoint i?  

I will run a few tests with different parameters  to compare t=
he 
Cantera results with the Chemkin II calculations. At present, I am 
qui=
te happy with the performance of the Cantera solver. 

Thank you very much =
for the excellent work.

Best regards,

Anatoli Mokhov
